description: From Latin monitor (“warner”), from perfect passive participle monitus (“warning”), from verb monere (“to warn, admonish, remind”).  Warship sense is from USS Monitor, the first ship of this type.

entries.meaning: Someone who watches over something; a person in charge of something or someone.
examples: The camp monitors look after the children during the night, when the teachers are asleep.

entries.meaning: A device that detects and informs on the presence, quantity, etc., of something.
(computing) A device similar to a television set used as to give a graphical display of the output from a computer.
examples: The information flashed up on the monitor.

entries.meaning: (computing) A program for viewing and editing.
(Hong Kong, archaic in Britain) A student leader in a class.

(nautical) One of a class of relatively small armored warships with only one or two turrets (but often carrying unusually large guns for a warship of its size), usually designed for shore bombardment or riverine warfare rather than open-ocean combat.  [from 1862]
(obsolete) One who admonishes; one who warns of faults, informs of duty, or gives advice and instruction by way of reproof or caution.
examples: You need not be a monitor to your gracious master the king.

entries.meaning: (engineering) A tool holder, as for a lathe, shaped like a low turret, and capable of being revolved on a vertical pivot so as to bring the several tools successively into position.

verbs.description: monitor (third-person singular simple present monitors, present participle monitoring, simple past and past participle monitored)

examples: A wide-area distributed system such as a Grid requires that a broad range of data be monitored and collected for a variety of tasks such as fault detection and performance monitoring, analysis, prediction and tuning.
